text:
Here's a fantasy scenario: imagine if Google decided to cease all prod dev and transition to become a static service within 18 months.

They automate the crap out of everything. Puts in extra server capacity. And cuts workforce to just enough to keep the lights on.

I don't think big tech should be broken up, but if FAMG released 20% of their workforce back into the wild, the amount of company creation would be mind blowing.

So many brilliant folks are just there polishing widgets. Cut the golden handcuffs. Unleash their potential.

Here's my basic tactic for personal growth: aim for something that you want to do, have no idea how to do, but that is 100% doable if you put in a decent amount of effort.

Why it's good: it's hard enough that it stimulates growth but not so hard that you give up.

Cooking before & after the internet:

Pre-internet: Read Julia Child. Practice one recipe religiously. If it doesn't work yell at the clouds.

Post-internet: watch 10 YouTube videos from Ramsay, Oliver, Gennaro, Pépin, Alex etc. Learn from many perspectives, go your own way.

text: 8/ Two decades on, Terminator 2 is not only a masterpiece of sci-fi, it predicted the technology stack of 2020 from AI to cloud computing, chip design to packaging. Arguably, it also sparked the debate on AI safety and spurred the creation of companies like OpenAI.

7/ Finally, T-800 chips are not square but cubes. This implies IC manufacturing has gone from 2D to 3D—chips stack on top of each other. In our world, we started shipping 3D memory about 5 years ago. TSMC’s 3D processor stacking technology is slated for production in 2021. https://t.co/dnkKtLkoyk

text: 5/ 2020's AMD Rome CPU is exactly that. Unlike the large monolithic CPUs of the past 40 years, AMD’s Rome processor is composed of 8 smaller CPUs tied together by a network chip, helping it to surpass Intel for the first time in over a decade. https://t.co/tGREnibznS
4/ The T-800 CPU is a 3x5 multi-chip design. It suggests monolithic integration (very large chips) has been replaced by a network of smaller chips, especially for “edge” applications such as robots.

text: 5/ Many companies have tried building ARM servers without success. Why? Linus Torvalds offers a simple explanation: developers want the cloud to run the same code as their laptops. Since devs code on x86 laptops, they want to deploy on x86 servers in the cloud. https://t.co/39saytPtuB

text: 4/ In a word—developers. Developers are the third force that influences which platforms win or lose. Apps are written for phones but not on phones. Almost all code is written on x86 PCs or x86 servers in the cloud. x86 has developers locked in.

3/ Today smartphones are by far the largest computer market. At $600B, it’s larger than PCs and servers combined. Smartphones use ARM CPUs while PCs and servers use x86. Through the forces of standards and scale, it ought to displace x86 CPUs in PCs and servers. Why hasn’t it? https://t.co/CH4ndN0Tba

8/ Neural nets are beating language benchmarks faster than benchmarks can be created.

Yet first hand experience contradicts this progress—Alexa/Siri/Google still lack basic common sense.

Why? Is it a matter of time to deployment or are diverse human questions just much harder?

text: 7/ Will SuperGLUE stand the test of time? It appears not. Six months in and the Google T5 model is within 1% of human performance. https://t.co/3sismk9qF4

6/ Progress in language-understanding was so rapid, the authors of GLUE was forced to create a new version of the benchmark “SuperGLUE” in 2019.

SuperGlue is HARD, far harder than a naive Turing Test. Just look at these prompts: https://t.co/LdRA7aUvlQ

5/ It took six years for neural nets to catch up to human performance in ImageNet.

Transformer based neural nets (BERT, GPT) beat human performance in GLUE in less than one year. https://t.co/aG2jO5ZFO1

4/ In language understanding, neural nets did well in single tasks such as WikiQA, TREC, and SQuAD but it wasn’t clear they could master a range of tasks like humans.

 Thus GLUE  was created—a set of 9 diverse language tasks that hopefully would keep researchers busy for years. https://t.co/jdvHWN6uGn

14/ As @ylecun has pointed out, hardware informs software. The kind of neural nets we have today is a function of the GPUs we have. If wafer sized chips become the norm, we could invent entire new classes of algorithms. Exciting days ahead! /fin
13/ Lastly, while it’s easy to get excited about what this will do for existing AI algorithms, whether it's 10x or 100x speedup on GPT-2 or BERT, the real excitement is what it will enable.

12/ Healthy skepticism is warranted. The industry has never seen anything like this before. It might not live up to these lofty goals for all kinds of reasons. Cerebras says they have customers in trials now and official benchmarks in November so we’ll see.

11/ Cerebras’ Wafer Scale Engine (WSE) is *one chip* holding 400,000 cores and 18GB of memory. Neural network training happens on one piece of silicon rather than spread across dozens of boards, servers, interconnects. If it works, one chip can replace a rack of GPU servers. https://t.co/IDcHGSuaKr

text:
10/ Large models like Google’s Neural Machine Translation don’t even fit in one GPU’s external memory. Often they have to be split up across dozens of GPUs/servers. This increases latency by another 10-100x.

Ideally the whole model fits on a single chip—that's Cerebras' WSE. https://t.co/04bB5BVbJm

9/ Neural nets can consume GBs of memory. GPUs only have MBs of on-chip memory. So GPUs store neural nets on external memory soldered next to it on the PCB.

The problem is external memory is 10-100x slower & more power hungry vs. on-chip memory. They are also very expensive. https://t.co/F6dViN329w

8/ Why is one giant chip better than a bunch of tiny ones?

Because you can fit the whole neural network on one chip rather than dice it up and spread it across dozens of GPUs. It is easier to program, way faster, and far more power efficient. https://t.co/UB2Udrs44B

text: 7/ Cerebras deals with defects through build-in redundancy. The chip has extra cores and I/O lanes built-in. If one core is a dud, data moves around it just as traffic is re-routed around a closed city block. According to Cerebras, only 1.5% of the hw is for redundancy. https://t.co/vbPa0PRq4x

6/ How did Cerebras get around the reticle limit and defect rate?

Their chips still use a conventional photomask and expose the wafer sections at a time. But they worked with TSMC to lay additional wires to wire all the chips together so they can work as a whole. https://t.co/oX6KmstLci

text:
5/ So what did Cerebras do? They made the largest chip ever—a chip the size of an entire wafer.

If this were pizza, Nvidia/Intel/AMD make 30cm pies and then cut them up and sell tiny 2cm^2 slices. Cerebras sells a giant uncut 21cm^2 slab. https://t.co/o9mEE8DcMs

4/ Second, defect rate. The larger the chip, the greater the chance for chip defects. As chip size grows, the defect rate -> 100%, yield -> 0%. It’s very hard to make large chips and still have enough working ones to sell. https://t.co/CFktgJW0x9
3/ First, the ASML lithography machines have a reticle size of 858mm^2. V100 is basically at the limit of what today's manufacturing allows. https://t.co/K2UXvRAfTI

text:
13/ Google/Deepmind has invested $$ millions into simulated solutions for Go and StarCraft. VCs have invested just as much in self driving startups.

Why is no one doing the obvious thing—demonstrating an L5 AI in simulation first?

/end
12/ The current approach of solving autonomy directly on real-world vehicles is like trying to solve Go on a laptop without having solved it first on a supercomputer.
11/ These are not easy problems, but at least they appear tractable. It turns a research problem into an optimization problem and those tend to get solved with time.

10/ Separately, you have to solve for accurate transfer of the simulated model to the real world. Granted simulations are imperfect and transfer is tricky. But we simulate many tricky things from molecular dynamics to nuclear weapons. Transfer should be a solvable problem.
9/ Now your problem is purely one of cost reduction and transfer. {XYZ} is likely greater than what can fit in a vehicle in 2019. We just need to invest and cost collapse those variables.

8/ Assume you manage to solve it in simulation. Now you have a performance target. You can say with full confidence that X petaflops of compute, Y resolution of sensors, and Z quantity of data solves for L5 in sim.

7/ IMO the first step to solving autonomy is to demonstrate it in a high-fidelity simulator. This is necessary but insufficient for solving L5 in real vehicles. If you can’t give such a demo then you have no chance of solving autonomy in real cars with worse compute/sensors.

text: 6/ How do we know this? A simulation is essentially that. In a simulator, you can tap into unlimited compute, the 3D engine gives you perfect ‘sensor data’, and you can run as many iterations as you want. Yet neither Google nor Nvidia has given such a demo.

5/ One way to clarify the question of autonomy is to ask: if you had unlimited compute resources, a perfect sensor set, and unlimited data, could you create an L5 AI? The answer thus far appears to be no.

text: 4/ What about data? Waymo has over 10 million miles of data. Tesla has over a billion miles of simpler data. If data is the constraint, then it must be well above these existing figures.

3/ What about sensors? Perhaps what’s needed is 10x resolution across vision/lidar/radar. If this were the case, we should have seen a demo already using the most high-end/cost-prohibitive/military versions of such sensors. No such demo exists.

2/ If autonomy were a function of having 'x' petaflops of compute performance, we should have seen a demo already. Just load a van with 10 DGX-2 servers (~20 petaflops) running the most elaborate neural net and drive around Rome/NY/Jakarta. No such demo exists.

1/ What is the primary obstacle to solving autonomous driving? Is it compute, sensors, algorithms, data or some combination of these?

Intended for rich vacationers, the futuristic park -- which is looked after by robotic "hosts" -- allows its visitors to live out their fantasies through artificial consciousness. "Westworld" is based on the 1973 Michael Crichton movie of the same name and features an all-star cast.

text:
Prediction—starting this year the onslaught of competition from Disney and others will push Netflix to be more innovative than they've ever been.

They will experiment on both UX and content. Analysts will re-assess their TAM as greater than just video.
@galffy Every at-scale internet company has to solve backend. Solving backend for tech is like solving logistics for retail; it's table stakes, not innovation.

Arguing against myself--they've done so little not because they are incapable but because they're thoughtful.

Not over-complicating the product requires extraordinary discipline.

Their growth shows it's working.

But I still can't help but think they could do MUCH better.

text:
Am I the only one who's completely and utterly unimpressed by Netflix's product innovation?

Their software is a grid of videos.

Their 'ML' is collaborative filtering + A/B testing of thumbnails.

Where is the tech? Where is the ambition?
@arjunblj and how do I know if a kid is having a birthday in NY? 😝
@vgr @fortelabs So "full gonzo mode" is what I'm doing. Nice. I like the ring of that.
@arjunblj which VR joint?

Oh look "globalism" doing good stuff for the world
https://t.co/JwOMSWX8HY

@wolfejosh @MeowWolf I guess it's just different POV. I was in Fidi yesterday and was borderline depressed. Everything built is from a bygone era. Hudson Yards is just TWC 2.0.

I want to feel like I'm living in the future. No city delivers that experience today.
@wolfejosh @sfiscience @MeowWolf Me too!

@wolfejosh @MeowWolf NYC may be all those things in piecemeal, but I certainly don't feel like my retina is being blasted with wonders like in Meow Wolf.

NYC needs an amusement park for the mind.
@wolfejosh @sfiscience @MeowWolf Josh, we *desperately* need a Meow Wolf in NYC.

text:
Important thread ⬇️

The more technological progress we have, the less tenable it becomes to blame poor people as just “lazy”.

Raw labor is just not as valuable/marketable as 100 years ago. https://t.co/cuw391OIbR
@jasonlk Bubbles are not about growth rates, they are about what people pay for such growth rates.

@BluegrassCap Cheap labor
High urban density
Subsidy wars
Cultural norms
@aruncann Agree++. That setup was so ridiculous I couldn't get into the movie at all.
@RyanSmithAT @4x1mux @anandtech As a reader, it does sound like they see discontinuing the product line.

Consumer vs. enterprise tech IPOs in the last 10 years:
Enterprise is not only ~6x more prolific, it's more rewarding:
37 enterprise companies returned >4x vs. only 5 for consumer.
FAANG has sucked the oxygen out of the room for consumer.
Paradoxically, enterprise is wide open. https://t.co/i3uSApnR7x
The better movie is:

@DataToViz "This will cost us more toner and paper so we will not implement it."
<- Hopefully not 😅
@benedictevans Ad market is very possibly driven more by expansion than share shift.
@yassineARK @fidelitylabs Nice adulting
@Androme67369792 Consciousness is not an emergent from computation, it’s emergent from sensory organs.
@EVSaltBlog Cameras and AI chips?
@gaspersopi Is it tho? Driving requires solving a good chunk of vision, language, and common sense.
@strangecosmos Responsible might be too strong a word. They might just run countless parallel simulations that produce outcomes they don’t even know ahead of time.
@Hvsssvn NeuralLink? Or one focused on hacking reality?

text:
The number one question on Zoom’s $ZM upcoming IPO is of course, competition.

Here is one way to view it. https://t.co/BOghKY2Wmk
Refactoring that Peter Lynch aphorism: "more money has been lost from fear of competition than competition itself."

I tried to find every example of large tech companies crushing smaller best-in-class pure plays. Here is the complete list:
• Microsoft -> Netscape
• Amazon AWS -> Rackspace
• FB/Instagram -> Snapchat

Three examples.

If I had to do the reverse the list would go on forever.

text: 6/ Fast interconnects are clearly very important for AI training. What’s not clear is why Nvidia has to *buy the company* rather than just buy the components as they do for CPUs, memory etc.
5/ For example the Summit and Sierra supercomputers—which have very similar designs to AI training clusters are based on lots of GPUs wired through NVlink and lots of nodes wired by InfiniBand.

4/ This is still not enough. To train the world’s most complex neural nets—or better still—to use AI to search for neural net architectures—requires hundreds of GPUs. And the only way to hook up dozens of such boxes is to use fast interconnects such as Mellanox InfiniBand.

2/ The slowdown in Moore’s Law has forced the industry to migrate to parallel computing. The key to making lots of chips work efficiently together is fast interconnects.

entity.description: A humanoid horse, BoJack Horseman -- lost in a sea of self-loathing and booze -- decides it's time for a comeback. Once the star of a '90s sitcom, in which he was the adoptive father of three orphaned kids (two girls and a boy). The show was the hottest thing around, then suddenly, was canceled. Now 18 years later, BoJack wants to regain his dignity. With the aid of a human sidekick and a feline ex-girlfriend who is his agent, he sets out to make it happen. But Hollywood is vastly different from those days, and getting used to stuff like Twitter may take some time. This first animated series from Netflix -- with plenty of references to sex, drugs and alcohol -- is not for the little ones.

@naval I guess we could say that "weak creativity" - finding solutions similar to existing solutions is addressable via machine learning.

But "strong creativity" - finding solutions vastly dissimilar to priors - requires human ingenuity or AGI.

Any business idea that is sufficiently novel will both *create* customers (your diehard fans) and *delete* customers (novelty alienates the mainstream).

The $$ question whether the net number is sufficiently large to support the enterprise.

@naval All creation is effectively some kind of traversal/search of the solution space. Machine learning is a systematized way of doing just that.

From a computer science perspective AlphaGo/AlphaStar "found" new game strategies. From a humanist perspective, it played "creative" games.

entity.description: When someone has cosmetic surgery, it doesn't always turn out as planned. So what happens when a procedure is botched? If they're on this reality series, they head to renowned plastic surgeons Paul Nassif and Terry Dubrow, who try to reverse damages from the original procedure. Each hourlong episode follows a patient through the process of correcting failed operations, from the complex procedures to the intensive recovery process and -- ultimately -- the reveal of the successful transformation.

Start with the 10min explainer video on YouTube.

Music is the closest thing to Feeling as a Service. 
Each song is a 3.5 minute containerized service that loads and replays a prior emotional state.
The library is the full list of songs/mind-states that can be executed on-demand.
FaaS vendors sell 40m mind-states for $10/m.

entity.name: Bojack Horseman
entity.description: A humanoid horse, BoJack Horseman -- lost in a sea of self-loathing and booze -- decides it's time for a comeback. Once the star of a '90s sitcom, in which he was the adoptive father of three orphaned kids (two girls and a boy). The show was the hottest thing around, then suddenly, was canceled. Now 18 years later, BoJack wants to regain his dignity. With the aid of a human sidekick and a feline ex-girlfriend who is his agent, he sets out to make it happen. But Hollywood is vastly different from those days, and getting used to stuff like Twitter may take some time. This first animated series from Netflix -- with plenty of references to sex, drugs and alcohol -- is not for the little ones.

entity.name: Bojack Horseman
entity.description: A humanoid horse, BoJack Horseman -- lost in a sea of self-loathing and booze -- decides it's time for a comeback. Once the star of a '90s sitcom, in which he was the adoptive father of three orphaned kids (two girls and a boy). The show was the hottest thing around, then suddenly, was canceled. Now 18 years later, BoJack wants to regain his dignity. With the aid of a human sidekick and a feline ex-girlfriend who is his agent, he sets out to make it happen. But Hollywood is vastly different from those days, and getting used to stuff like Twitter may take some time. This first animated series from Netflix -- with plenty of references to sex, drugs and alcohol -- is not for the little ones.

text: @cptwei Moore's Law is just a plot device in the first episode.

The internet is 24 years old.

As a person, it is younger than most people on earth.

There's been nothing that has been as transformative in such a short period of time.

Yet zoom out a little, and we're still at chapter 1, page 1.

The story has barely begun.

To get a sense of just how early we are in the technology epoch, consider the fact that people who were born before the transistor are still alive today.

If human technological progress were a five-season TV show, we are currently maybe ten minutes into the first episode.
